metadata.title: Heterostructured TiO2/C/Co from ZIF-67 Frameworks for Microwave- Absorbing Nanomaterials

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text:
In the past decade, rapid development in the telecommunication and digital industry has generated an extortionate amount of electromagnetic (EM) radiation in the environment. Electromagnetic interference (EMI) has been categorized as a pollutant and is a ecting human health. The most adverse e ects of prolonged exposure to EM radiation are eyestrain, fatigue, headaches, and sleep disturbance. Furthermore, electromagnetic interference (EMI) has become a great concern for physical health, biological systems, and information safety.1 Therefore, it is mandatory to develop advanced electromagnetic shielding materials to minimize the health hazards associated with EMI.2 4 Typically impedance matching and EM attenuation capability are the standard mechanisms for designing the EM absorption material.5 However, phonon interaction is also an important phenomenon that needs to be considered for an e cient EM absorbing material.
When electromagnetic waves interact with matter, they usually transfer some amount of energy to the atoms or molecules creating lattice vibrations called phonons.6 These phonons play a crucial role in the thermal and electrical conductivity.7 The phonons can disseminate in the lattice of a single crystal as a wave and create dispersion depending on their wavelength or equivalently their wavevector in the
Brillouin zone.8,9 Phonon propagation is interrupted when a grain boundary is encountered in a polycrystalline material. In an isolated grain, the phonon can be re ected from the boundaries and remain con ned within the grain. In nanoscale heterostructures, electronic states exist as quantized sub-band energy levels. These levels are responsible for absorbing low energy phonons in the infrared and terahertz regions.10 In principle, phonons can interact with EM radiation of lower frequencies like microwaves.11 The con nement of charge carriers can alter the optical properties drastically. Similarly, con nement of phonons also leads to interesting changes in the phonon spectra, which leads to the appearance of new modes in the microwave frequency range.9,12
Porous carbon materials derived from the metal organic framework (MOF) have gained attention in catalysis,13 electrode materials,14 and surface modi cation15 applications because of their large surface area, high electrical conductivity, and adjustable pores structure.16 There have been some reports suggesting that lightweight porous carbons are a good candidate for EM absorption.17 21 However, it is di cult for an individual material to respond to a broad range of

frequencies. Integrating the aforementioned excellent properties of di erent materials into heterostructure will lead to novel electronic and orbital properties. These heterostructures demonstrate admirable properties and play a key role in the EM absorption.22 25
As previously reported, highly ordered nanoporous carbon with magnetic cobalt has been prepared by thermal decomposition of Co-based zeolitic imidazolate framework material (ZIF-67).13,26 Unfortunately, in the high frequency range (GHz) ZIF-67 did not manifest good EM absorption properties due to its relatively high complex permittivity value leading to impedance mismatch. Ji et al. investigated the improvement of impedance matching and prepared a Co/TiO2 composite and illustrated enhanced results in terms of impedance matching.27 Generally speaking, there are several techniques to enhance impedance matching such as (1) producing vacancies or pores into the absorbing material, (2) making the layered composite materials, (3) wrapping the EM absorbing material with SiO2 or Al2O3 to decrease the complex permittivity and enhance the impedance matching.4 Nanostructured titanium dioxide (TiO2) is broadly considered in EM absorption because of its relatively lower value of the real part of complex permittivity and good dielectric loss.28,29 More importantly, there are several previous reports on phonon con nement in anatase nanocrystallites TiO2 which may help us to prepare a new route for microwave absorption in terms of phonons.30 TiO2 coating can also activate the synergistic e ect of multiple dielectric interfacial dielectric relaxations and phonon con nement to attenuate the EM waves at the interface of TiO2 and ZIF-67. 31 33
Here, we report a novel kind of heterostructured TiO2/C/ Co composite synthesized through the carbonized ZIF-67 (CZ) with di erent TiO2 coating times, which not only retains the advantages of porous ZIF-67 framework (lightweight, coste ective, and porous structure) but also modulates the thickness of TiO2 easily by adjustment of the coating time or amount of precursor. More interestingly, we demonstrate that the as-prepared TiO2/C/Co heterostructures show a substantially enhanced microwave absorption performance, which can be attributed to the improved impedance matching based on multiple interfacial dielectric relaxations at di erent dielectric media (TiO2/C, C/Co) as well as the phonon con nement in TiO2 coating layer with di erent thickness. As con nement of phonons has not been reported for microwave absorption, this work signify the new possible mechanism of electromagnetic shielding in a con ned system with multiple interfaces and may lead to design advanced materials for microwave shielding.

sections.heading: 2. EXPERIMENTAL SECTION
sections.text:
As shown in Scheme 1, TiO2@CZ has been prepared by in situ hydrolysis of titanium isopropoxide after the carbonization of ZIF-67. Two TiO2@CZ samples with di erent TiO2 coating thickness have been prepared. The thickness can be easily altered by varying the coating time or amount of titanium isopropoxide. For our case, we have varied the coating time from 2 to 24 h. For the convenience of understanding, we named samples as ZIF-67, CZ (carbonized ZIF67), TiO2@CZ_2h, and TiO2@CZ_24h.
2.1. Chemicals. 2-Methylimidazole (C4H6N2; 98%, Aladin corporation), cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O; 99%, Aladin corporation), methanol (CH3OH; 99.5%, Sinopharm chemical reagent co.), ammonia solution (NH3; 99%, Sinopharm chemical reagent co.), and titanium(IV) isopropoxide (C12H28O4Ti; 99.9%,
Aladin corporation) are used for this work. All of the used reagents were analytical grade with high purity.
2.2. Synthesis of Carbonized ZIF-67. In a typical synthesis, cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (0.25 mol, 0.546 g) was dissolved in 7.5 mL methanol and 2-methylimidazole (0.5 mol, 0.6 g) dissolved in 15 mL methanol under magnetic stirring separately. These two solutions were mixed together. The obtained solution turned purple and was transfer to 50 mL autoclave placed at 100 °C for 4 h. After heating, the precipitates were collected by centrifuged and washed with methanol several times and dried at 60 °C overnight. The dried precipitates were carbonized in the presence of nitrogen (N2) gas at 500 °C for 3 h in a tube furnace.
2.3. Synthesis of Composites TiO2@CZ (TiO2/C/Co). A 50 mg portion of carbonized ZIF-67 was added into 200 mL ethanol and water solution with 3:1 ratio, respectively. A 1.5 mL portion of ammonia solution added dropwise into the solution under magnetic stirring. A 1 mL portion of titanium isopropoxide was added to the solution slowly at room temperature and stirred for 2 h. Then, the solution was ltered and the obtained precipitates were washed with water and ethanol. After that, precipitates were placed in an oven at 60 °C for drying. The same procedure was repeated again with 24 h stirring after the addition of titanium isopropoxide. At the end, the obtained products were annealed at 500 °C for 4 h in N2 atm with a heating rate of 5 °C/min.34
2.4. Material Characterization. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM-2100) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Hitachi S-4800) utilized for the morphology of as-prepared ZIF-67, carbonized ZIF-67 (CZ), and TiO2@CZ_24h. X-ray di raction (XRD, Rigaku D/MAX-cA) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ESCALAB 250) employed for structure analysis. The Raman spectrum was measured by using LabRAM HR800 Raman spectroscope ( ex = 532 nm). The Brunauer Emmett Teller (BET) surface area of the samples was measured on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 analyzer by N2 adsorption at 196 °C. EM absorption measurements were carried out by Agilent E5071 C vector network analyzer in the frequency range of 2 18 GHz. The prepared composite material was mixed with para n wax and pressed into a mold to obtained required toroidal shape with 7 mm outer diameter and 3.04 mm inner diameter. The specimen was inserted tightly into coaxial airline (25 internal resistance) and the permittivity and permeability of material were measured. Re ection loss measurements were done using a short S11 technique with di erent sample thicknesses of 1.8, 2, 2.5, 3, 3.5, and 4 mm.
Scheme 1. Flowchart of the Synthesis of Carbonized ZIF-67,

sections.text:
Characteristics

sections.heading: 3. RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
sections.text:
Figure 1a and b show the representative SEM and TEM images of ZIF-67, the product is clearly composed of crystals containing rhombic dodecahedral morphology. Figure 1c shows the SEM image of TiO2@CZ_2h, displaying TiO2 coating with rhombic dodecahedral shape and many pores on the surface. Figure 1d f shows the morphology of the spheres after the coating time was increased to 24 h. TEM images of TiO2@CZ_24h show clear nanospheres meaning that the excessive amount of TiO2 coating on CZ transformed its morphology to nanospheres. The elemental color mappings (Figure 1g k) con rms the coating of TiO2 and demonstrates the existence of Ti, O, C, and Co elements in the composite of TiO2@CZ_24h. In elemental mapping, Figure 1g has an overlapped image of all elemental compositions while the next gures (Figure 1h-k) are the derivatives from Figure 1g.
Figure 2a b displays the high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HR-TEM) images of carbonized ZIF67. The sample displays amorphous carbon with Co nanoparticles regularly embedded in the carbon matrix. The HR-TEM images of CZ show the Co nanoparticles with an average size of 5 nm while the interplane fringes distance is 0.17 nm, corresponds to the (200) crystal plane of cobalt.35 In Figure 2c d, HR-TEM images of TiO2@CZ_2h sample shows the carbonized ZIF-67 enveloped by TiO2 shells. The interplane spacing between lattice fringes is 0.35 nm corresponds to the (101) facet of anatase TiO2. 33 Figure
Figure 1. (a) SEM and (b) TEM images of ZIF-67, (c) SEM image of TiO2@CZ_2h, (d f) TEM images of TiO2@CZ_24h, (g k) elemental color mapping of TiO2@CZ_24h.
2e f illustrates the formation of the TiO2@CZ_24h sample. There is a more width of anatase TiO2 shells covering the carbonized ZIF-67 indicating an excessive width of TiO2 shells converts the rhombic dodecahedral shape of carbonized ZIF67 to the spheres. The clear lattice fringes could also con rm that the TiO2 shells of the TiO2@CZ_24h sample are highly crystalline. The HR-TEM observations con rmed that carbonized ZIF-67 consists of Co nanoparticles embedded in amorphous carbon while it completely covered by the anatase TiO2 shells.
The phase and structure of ZIF-67, CZ, and TiO2@CZ_24h have been characterized by X-ray di raction (XRD) techniques. It can be seen from Figure 3a that ZIF-67 is highly crystalline while after being carbonized at 500 °C it converts to porous carbon with cobalt nanoparticles. The peak of Co at 44.5° matches with JCPDS card no. 15-0806.18,19 The TiO2 has been coated directly on this porous carbon surface via the in situ hydrolysis synthesis route. After the hydrolysis process, the obtained amorphous TiO2 layer is further crystallized by heat treatment at 500 °C for 4 h under nitrogen gas. The XRD peaks of the obtained TiO2@CZ_24h at 25°, 53°, 62.6°, and 75° match with anatase TiO2 with the JCPDS card no. 21-1272, which corresponds to (101), (105), (204), and (215) planes of anatase TiO2.
36 XPS survey spectrum of TiO2@CZ_24h (Figure 3b) shows the elemental compositions of cobalt (Co, 780 eV), titanium (Ti, 458 eV), carbon (C, 284 eV), and oxygen (O, 530 eV). Further, Figure 3c shows the Co 2p XPS spectrum in which two primary spin orbital peaks at 780 eV (Co 2p3/2) and 796 eV (Co 2p1/2) corresponding to metallic Co,37 and two shakeup satellites are present; these characteristics belong to Co2+.38 The spin orbital splitting of Ti 2p3/2 and Ti 2p1/2 are located at binding energies of 458.5 and 464.2 eV, respectively, as seen in Figure 3d. The separation between the Ti 2p3/2 and Ti 2p1/2 peaks is 5.7 eV that is in good agreement with the reported literature values.39 The peak of carbon in Figure 3e can be split into three components, belongs to sp2 and sp3 carbon, the second
and third peak correspond to C O/C O and O C O.40 Figure 3f represents the O 1s peaks for TiO2@CZ_24h designating to O2 at 529.75 eV and a hydroxyl ( OH) shoulder peak located at 531 eV.41
Heterostructured materials contain multiple interfaces of two or more solid-state materials with unequal bandgaps. The heterostructured materials are advantageous to produce new electronic energy bands with new bandgaps. To ensure the formation of heterostructure of TiO2/C/Co, UV vis absorption spectrum has been measured in the wavelength range of 200 800 nm. Figure S1a shows three-band absorption of as-synthesized ZIF-67 rhombic dodecahedrons with absorption maxima at 358, 641, and 693 nm, respectively. These features can be assigned to the ligand-to-metal chargetransfer (LMCT) character.42 In Figure S1b the carbonized ZIF-67 shows no absorption peak suggesting a signi cant change of thermal decomposition into amorphous carbon with Co nanoparticles. After the TiO2 coating on carbonized ZIF67, the TiO2@CZ_2h exhibit a weak absorption edge at the wavelength range around 420 nm, while the sample TiO2@ CZ_24h display a strong absorption edge at 400 nm demonstrating the UV light response performance Figure S1c d. The band gap of samples has been measured through the re ectance coe cient ( ) using the Kubelka Munk equation ( hv = A(hv Eg)n where h is Planck s constant, Eg is the band gap energy, v is frequency, A is a constant that depends on the transition probability, and n is the power index that is related to the optical absorption process. The value of n depends on the direct and indirect bandgap transition. For an indirect allowed transition, the value of n = 2, (plotted as ( hv)1/2 versus energy (eV)) and n = 1/2 for a direct allowed transition (plotted as ( hv)2 versus energy (eV)). Figure S2a displays obtained direct band gap values for pristine ZIF-67 were 1.96, 3.65, and 4.06 eV, respectively. The carbonized ZIF67 or Co/C interface shows no bandgap indicating a nonsemiconducting material (Figure S2b). Coupling of TiO2 with carbonized ZIF-67, the indirect bandgap of TiO2@
Figure 3. (a) XRD of ZIF-67, CZ, and TiO2@CZ_24h, (b) XPS survey spectrum, and XPS spectra of high-resolution (c) Co 2p spectrum, (d) Ti 2p spectrum, (e) C 1s spectrum, and (f) O 1s spectrum of the TiO2@CZ_24h.
DOI: 10.1021/acsanm.9b00841 ACS Appl. Nano Mater. 2019, 2, 4451 4461 4454
CZ_2h and TiO2@CZ_24h obtained at the edge of the visible spectrum, which is 3.05 and 3.26 eV respectively (Figure S2c d).43 The sample TiO2@CZ_2h shows low absorption at bandgap and the trend of carbonized ZIF-67 can be seen while TiO2@CZ_24h shows strong absorption indicating dominance of TiO2 layer.
The surface areas and pore size distribution of ZIF-67 and TiO2@CZ_24h were investigated by N2 adsorption desorption isotherms (Figure S3). The speci c surface area, pore size, and pore volume were examined and summarized in Table S1. The surface area of TiO2@CZ_24h is 31.34 m2/g, slightly increased compared with ZIF-67 that has 27.18 m2/g, while the pore size distribution curves show the great di erence. The pores are enhanced in the composite structure by showing more tendency for N2 adsorption and desorption. The fact that higher pores are endorsed is due to the large molecule structure of titanate isopropoxide, which increases the movement to nanopores channels. The TiO2 shells are large porous structure compared to original ZIF-67. These pores in TiO2@CZ_24h o er more active sites for the scattering and re ection of EM waves, encouraging the repeated absorption process for higher e ciency.44 Further, the thermogravimetric
analysis (TGA) of ZIF-67, TiO2@CZ_2h, and TiO2@CZ_24h is shown in Figure S4. The TGA shows the higher thermal stability of the TiO2@CZ_24h sample in the presence of nitrogen gas. On the other hand, ZIF-67 start decomposing at a lower temperature possibly due to the escape of guest molecules including the decomposition of signi cant carbon inside it.45
Raman spectroscopy is an important tool for structural characterizations, e.g. to investigate oxygen defects, crystalline phase transitions, phonon interactions, stress states, and quantum size e ects in transition metal oxides.46,47 For TiO2, it is a very convenient tool to identify the crystalline phases such as rutile, anatase, and brookite. Figure 4 shows the Raman spectra of ZIF-67, carbonized ZIF-67, TiO2@CZ_2h, and TiO2@CZ_24h. In TiO2@CZ_24h Raman spectra, the peaks observed at 150, 403, 515, and 638 cm 1 correspond to the characteristic anatase phase of titanium dioxide.46,48 A careful investigation of Raman spectra of TiO2@CZ_2h and TiO2@CZ_24h have not shown the presence of rutile or brookite phase. The anatase phase of TiO2 is tetragonal with two formula units per unit cell (group D4h19).
30 In the Raman spectrum of anatase TiO2, the peak shift and broadening of full
Figure 4. (a) Raman spectra of ZIF-67, CZ, TiO2@CZ_2h, and TiO2@CZ_24h and (b) magni ed Raman spectra from 100 to 1000 cm 1.
Figure 5. Frequency dependence of electromagnetic parameters of ZIF-67, CZ, TiO2@CZ_2h, and TiO2@CZ_24h (a) real part and (b) imaginary part of complex permittivity, (c) real part ( ), and (d) imaginary part ( ) of complex permeability.
DOI: 10.1021/acsanm.9b00841 ACS Appl. Nano Mater. 2019, 2, 4451 4461 4455
width at half-maximum (fwhm) of characteristic anatase mode have been reported as either nonstoichiometric or phonon con nement in the nanocrystals. Balaji et al. reported these peaks and broadening as phonon con nement in anatase TiO2 and compared it with quantum size con nement.30 The peak positions and broadening in the Raman spectra of TiO2@ CZ_2h and TiO2@CZ_24h are in agreement with researchers who attributed that these peaks in Raman spectra essentially appear from the con nement of phonons in the outer layer of anatase TiO2 on carbonized ZIF-67. 49
For an in nite crystal, phonon scattering process takes place because of Raman active optical phonons near to the Brillouin zone center. In nanocrystals that have a diameter 10 nm, phonons are localized in the dimensions of nanocrystallites.30 The literature reveals that phonons can lead a vital role in the microwave absorption process.50 52
It is accepted that, for an excellent absorber, there are two main factors. The impedance matching is the rst that requires the equality of EM wave parameters; the second is the high EM wave attenuation in the interior of absorbing material. In view of this understanding, the microwave absorption mechanism of ZIF-67, CZ, TiO2@CZ_2h, and TiO2@ CZ_24h, the permittivity ( r) and permeability ( r) were measured in the 2 18 GHz range. The real part of permittivity and permeability belongs to the storage capability of the electric and magnetic energy, while imaginary parts ( , ) represent the strength of electric and magnetic energy loss.53 Figure 5 demonstrates the dependence of complex permittivity and permeability in the high frequency range. For ZIF-67 and CZ, the and values are very high as compared with the composites of TiO2@CZ_2h and TiO2@CZ_24h (Figure 5a b) while the values of and are weak for all samples (Figure 5c d). Consequently, the impedance matching of ZIF67 and carbonized ZIF-67 is very poor due to the bigger di erence of values of and . The poor impedance matching indicates that most of the EM waves are re ected back from the material surface, causing to lower EM wave absorption. As shown in Figure 4a b, the values become lower for the TiO2@CZ_2h and TiO2@CZ_24h and values gradually increased from one to four. Usually, the real permittivity is an expression of polarization capability of a material that mostly ascends from interfacial polarization and dipolar polarization at gigahertz frequency range.54 In this situation, along with dipolar polarization and interfacial polarization, the con nement of phonons in the outer layer of TiO2 plays an important role in the impedance matching. The phonon con nement inside the lattice leads to lower the strength of formation of E- eld from the surface. The strategy is that the inside C/Co leads toward high magnetic loss while the surface leads to high electric loss. Moreover, the thickness of TiO2 in uences the permittivity and permeability of di erent TiO2@CZ_x samples. After coating TiO2, the pore volume of TiO2@CZ_24h increases according to the results of Table S1. The interface between TiO2 and CZ increases, which leads to the enhancement of interfacial polarization. As a result, compared with ZIF-67 and CZ, impedance matching of TiO2@CZ_24h has been excellently enhanced. The synergistic e ect of both these parameters leads to high impedance matching for high re ection loss inside the TiO2@CZ_24h composite. It is noteworthy that at 2.5 mm thickness the curves of TiO2@CZ_24h shows two notable resonance peaks at 12 and 14 GHz frequency (Figure S5). These peaks may be attributed to interfacial polarization due to the interface
between ZIF-67 and TiO2 coating, and the phonons that have dispersion over a wide range of frequencies propagating through the layers with zonefolding e ects. These facts propose that the TiO2@CZ composite has a decent dielectric interface and electromagnetic interaction properties.
The e ect of coating time of TiO2 shells in terms of complex permittivity and permeability was also studied. The results revealed that EM parameters ( r, r) and absorption properties of TiO2@CZ directly in uenced by the coating durations of TiO2. From Figure 5a, it can be seen that the real part of permittivity decreases with an increase in coating time of TiO2. The logarithmic law of mixing is the most common equation for a multiphase composite aimed at prediction of dielectric constant, as shown in eq 1).55
= + + V V Vln ln ln ln1 1 2 2 3 3 (1)
Where 1 , 2 , and 3 are the real part of permittivity and V1, V2, and V3 are volume fractions of CZ, TiO2, and air, respectively. When the thickness of TiO2 shells increases, V2 also increase and other fraction volumes decrease. By individual, 1 is much larger than 2 , but the change in the volume fraction in uenced the collective permittivity and therefore reduced with an increase in the coating time. A comparatively lower is favorable for impedance matching. However, it is not necessarily the case that smaller is good for EM wave absorption, because is also related to the by the Debye relaxation model eqs 2 and 3.56
= + f/2 (2)

f2 o (3)
Referring to eq 2, the lower will also lead to low imaginary permittivity (hence, low dielectric loss). In eq 3, is electrical conductivity and o is the free space dielectric constant. The Debye equation is directly related to the interfacial dielectric relaxation. At the interface, the dielectric constant delays or changes. This is caused by the interface molecular polarization. Equation 3 expresses that an increase in electrical conductivity leads to high imaginary permittivity. Equations 2 and 3 explains very well that, for an excellent EM absorption material, there is a critical balance required between the values of real and imaginary permittivity.
Attenuation constant ( ) is another useful parameter that de nes the attenuation of microwaves in the material. The can be measured by eq 4.57

Where c is the speed of light, f is frequency, and , , , and are the real and imaginary parts of permittivity and permeability. As shown in Figure S6 the composite of TiO2@ CZ_2h and 24h has higher values in all frequency range, indicating the excellent attenuation. It is known that the magnetic loss for microwave absorption originates from eddy current e ects, hysteresis, domain wall resonance, and natural resonance for the nanostructured materials. However, when the applied eld is weak, the hysteresis loss is negligible and domain wall displacement loss does not arise at high frequency. For ZIF-67 and CZ, the values of ( ) 2f 1 shows straight
DOI: 10.1021/acsanm.9b00841 ACS Appl. Nano Mater. 2019, 2, 4451 4461 4456
line behavior, which speci es that magnetic loss may arise through the eddy current e ects (Figure 6a).58
The value of Co for TiO2@CZ_2h and TiO2@CZ_24h varies in the entire frequency range of 2 18 GHz (Figure 6a). We know that the Co value remains constant if the eddy current loss is the only participant toward the magnetic loss. However, the variation peaks arise in the Co value tends toward the natural resonance, which may be the main phenomena to the magnetic loss of composite. This magnetic loss leads to the wider bandwidth and enhances the minimal value of re ection loss (Figure 6b). The magnetic (tan ) and dielectric tangent loss (tan ) are calculated from eqs 5 and 6. 59
= tan (5)
= tan (6)
The tan and tan are key parameters to evaluate the microwave absorption properties for an absorber. As shown in
Figure S7a dielectric tangent loss of TiO2@CZ_2h and TiO2@ CZ_24h are much higher compared with the ZIF-67 and CZ. It may have the same reason for impedance matching strategy that makes fewer re ections from the surface and transfers the energy of EM waves to lattice vibrations (phonons) inside the TiO2@CZ composite. In comparison, magnetic tangent loss (Figure S7b) of TiO2@CZ_24h has a prominent magnetic loss from the 2 10 GHz frequency range. Figure S8 shows the magnetic hysteresis loop; it can be seen in Figure S8a that ZIF67 shows diamagnetic behavior. Meanwhile, the CZ shows a weak ferromagnetic behavior with a low saturation magnetization. Besides, the TiO2@CZ_2h and TiO2@CZ_24h shows paramagnetic behavior at the applied magnetic eld (Figure S8b). Titanium oxide (TiO2) is normally known for paramagnetic behavior. The TiO2@CZ_24h sample shows a larger magnetic loss as compared to pristine ZIF-67 and carbonized ZIF-67 (Figure S8b). The discussion about dielectric and magnetic tangent loss and attenuation constant can predict that TiO2@CZ_2h and TiO2@CZ_24h possess higher
Figure 6. (a) Co values of ZIF-67, CZ, TiO2@CZ_2h, and TiO2@CZ_24h and (b) minimum re ection loss of TiO2@CZ_24h with corresponding bandwidth shown.
Figure 7. Re ection loss (RL) values of (a) ZIF-67, (b) CZ, (c) TiO2@CZ_2h, and (d) TiO2@CZ_24h.
DOI: 10.1021/acsanm.9b00841 ACS Appl. Nano Mater. 2019, 2, 4451 4461 4457
capability of transforming electromagnetic waves into di erent forms of energy, i.e. phonons.
Generally, the e ciency of microwave absorption of the material is estimated by re ection loss (RL) value. At the selected range of frequency (2 18 GHz), the measured complex permittivity and complex permeability values used as RL coe cients. The re ection loss can be calculated by the following eqs 7 and 8.35,60
c

f
h g g g g g g g gg =Z Z j fd c tanh 2 ( )in o r r r r 1/2
(7)
= | + |Z Z Z ZRL 20log ( )/( )in o in o (8)
Where Zo is free space impedance, Zin is the input impedance, f is the frequency, and c is the velocity of light. Practically, the MW absorbing materials are required to achieve RL values less than 10 dB which indicates more than 90% of incident EM waves dissipated in the material. Figure 7 illustrates the variation of RL values at 2 18 GHz frequency for ZIF-67 (Figure 7a), CZ (Figure 7b), TiO2@CZ_2h (Figure 7c), and TiO2@CZ_24h (Figure 7d) at di erent sample thickness (1 4 mm). For ZIF-67 and carbonized ZIF-67, it is clearly seen that RL values are not lower than 12 dB, the poor re ection loss of ZIF-67 was already expected from the very low impedance matching and insu cient tangent loss. These low values indicate that individual ZIF-67 cannot be used for practical applications. It is pleasing that the two improved samples of TiO2@CZ_2h and TiO2@ZIF67 24h show excellent MW absorption performance. For TiO2@CZ_2h (Figure 7c), the maximum RL of 27 dB obtained at 7.14 GHz and the RL values less than 10 dB gained in the entire thickness range from 1 to 4 mm. For TiO2@CZ_24h (Figure 7d), an optimum RL of 42 dB was obtained at 11.5 GHz with 2.5 mm sample thickness and wide bandwidth of 5 GHz. The variation of RL values below 1.5 mm thickness for ZIF-67 and CZ clearly shows that RL values are not more than 7 to 13 dB, respectively, indicating poor re ection loss of ZIF-67 and CZ that is predicted by the low impedance matching and insu cient tangent loss. For TiO2@CZ_2h, the max RL of
18 dB is attained at 6 GHz. While the TiO2@CZ_24h sample attained an optimum RL of 32 dB at 6.3 GHz with 1.5 mm sample thickness, the results show that sample TiO2@ CZ_24h has a higher performance even at smaller sample width. Besides, the simple dependence of RL on frequency, a 3D graph of ZIF-67, CZ, TiO2@CZ_2h, and TiO2@CZ_24h with sample thickness are obtained and shown in Figure S9.
The quarter-wavelength model, in which the bond between peak frequency ( f) and sample thickness (d) described as the following eq 9, can also analyze the dependence of RL values on the sample thickness.61,62
= | || | d
nc
f4 r r (9)
According to the above equation, the absorption peaks move toward lower frequency range with the increase in the sample thickness, if the r, r remains constant over the frequency range. Moreover, based on eq 7 when Zin approaches Zo and sample thickness satis es eq 9, the lowest RL value can be attained. Compared with MW absorption characteristics of the pristine ZIF-67, the results demonstrated that the TiO2@ CZ_2h and TiO2@CZ_24h have outstanding absorption in the broad frequency range of 2 18 GHz with 1 4 mm thickness pointing toward the applications of MW absorption over the complete frequency range, which can be attained by adjusting the matching thickness and coating thickness of the TiO2 layer on the surface of ZIF-67.
63 Furthermore, in Table S2, TiO2 and ZIF based composites and their microwave absorption performance have been listed from the literature. It is clear to notice that the prepared composite TiO2@CZ_24h exhibited good MW absorption with broad bandwidth. In addition, the density of TiO2@CZ_24h valued to be 3.13 g/ cm3, which is relatively lower than the traditional MW absorbing materials such as transition metals and ferrites.23 It is pleasing that the prepared samples of TiO2@CZ_24h not only have good absorption strength but also have a low density for practical applications.
Figure 8 demonstrates the possible mechanism of re ection loss and wider bandwidth. Like the earlier discussion about
Figure 8. Possible mechanism of re ection loss and wide bandwidth.
DOI: 10.1021/acsanm.9b00841 ACS Appl. Nano Mater. 2019, 2, 4451 4461 4458
phonon con nement and Debye dielectric relaxation, when the incident EM wave passes through the porous surface of TiO2@ CZ_24h, it encounters two di erent interfaces: (1) between the TiO2 layer and carbonized ZIF-67 and (2) carbon and cobalt inside the carbonized ZIF-67. According to Debye theory, EM wave faces a time leg caused by the interfacial dielectric relaxations that lead to the dissipation of EM wave.64
The reasons why TiO2@CZ_24h showed excellent microwave absorption are (1) the perfect impedance matching that allows EM waves to get inside the composite rather than be re ected; (2) the phonon con nement and multiple interface dielectric relaxation from the interfaces of the composite.49,64
These phenomena collectively played their role in the attenuation of EM waves and lead to maximum re ection loss. In Figure S10 the comparison of RL values (absorption strength) and absorption bandwidth at di erent sample thicknesses is shown. Compared with others, TiO2@CZ_24h has shown a decent EM absorption performance (Figure S10a) for all thickness range and the wide bandwidth for all the sample thickness (Figure S10b). All of the above results indicate that TiO2 played a bene cial role for the phonon con nement and interface dielectric relaxation that consequently enhanced the absorption e ciency of electromagnetic waves.

sections.heading: 4. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text:
Combining excellent properties of di erent materials, we successfully synthesized heterostructured composites of TiO2@CZ with di erent TiO2 coating time by a simple solvothermal and in situ hydrolysis route. TiO2@CZ retained the advantages (lightweight, high EM attenuation, etc.) of ZIF67, and in the meantime, TiO2 plays its role in phonon con nement and interfacial dielectric relaxations. The heterostructured composite allowed the synergistic e ect of multiple interfacial dielectric relaxations, dipole polarization, and phonon con nement to achieve the maximum attenuation that leads to the stunning microwave absorption performance of TiO2@CZ_2h and TiO2@CZ_24h. For 40% wt TiO2@ CZ_24h, the maximum achieved re ection loss was 42 dB with 5 GHz wide bandwidth (7.2 12.2 GHz). The results proposed that con nement of phonons in TiO2 could open a new path for the understanding of the microwave absorption mechanism.

metadata.abstractText: Heterostructured TiO2/C/Co nanomaterial has been derived from a carbonized zeolitic imidazolate (ZIF-67) porous framework. The obtained uniform nanospheres wrapped with TiO2 have shown superior microwave absorption properties. Traditionally, the interaction of phonons within a con ned system in terms of microwave absorption has not been studied in the literature to date. Here, we demonstrate that the phonon con nement is pivotal in the improvement of impedance matching, besides the multiple interfacial dielectric relaxations at di erent dielectric media (TiO2/C, C/Co) in the composite. Because of the specially crafted phonon con nement and multiple interface dielectric relaxations, the as-synthesized (TiO2/C/Co) composite manifests a maximum re ection loss of 42 dB with a broad bandwidth of 5 GHz. This work explains the possible mechanism of electromagnetic shielding in a con ned system with multiple interfaces and may lead to design of advanced materials for microwave shielding.
